sen.j: 伏見藩（ふしみはん）は、山城国伏見（現在の京都府京都市伏見区）に存在した藩。
sen.e: The domain of Fushimi was the one which existed in Fushimi in the Province of Yamashiro (Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture in the present day).
The domain of Fushimi existed in Fushimi in the Province of Yamashiro (present day Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture).
The Fushimi Domain existed in Fushimi in the Yamashiro Province (present day Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture).

sen.j: 居城は伏見城。
sen.e: The castle of a daimyo was Fushimi Castle.
The castle of a daimyo was Fushimi Castle.
The castle of a daimyo was Fushimi Castle.

sen.j: 伏見城は豊臣秀吉によって築城された。
sen.e: Fushimi Castle was constructed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
Fushimi-jo Castle was constructed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
Fushimi-jo Castle was constructed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 伏見の大地震によって倒壊したこともあったが、早くに再建されて豊臣時代には秀吉の繁栄を示すシンボル、そして一大政治都市として発展した。
sen.e: The castle collapsed under the great Fushimi earthquake but was reconstructed quickly, and it became the symbol of prosperity of Hideyoshi in the Toyotomi Period, and the town was developed as a big governmental city.

Altough the castle was destroyed in the great Fushimi earthquake, it was quickly reconstructed, and became a symbol of the prosperity of Hideyoshi in the Toyotomi Period, with the town becoming an important adminstrative center.

Although the castle was destroyed in the great Fushimi earthquake, it was quickly reconstructed, and became a symbol of the prosperity of Hideyoshi in the Toyotomi Period, with the town becoming an important administrative center.

sen.j: 慶長3年（1598年）8月18日に秀吉が生涯を閉じたのも、この伏見城においてである。
sen.e: It was this Fushimi Castle where Hideyoshi ended his days on August 18, 1598.
It was in Fushimi-jo Castle that Hideyoshi ended his days on August 18, 1598.
It was in Fushimi-jo Castle that Hideyoshi ended his days on August 18, 1598.

sen.j: 秀吉没後、伏見城には徳川家康が入り、最大実力者として政治を取り仕切った。
sen.e: After the death of Hideyoshi, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA moved in Fushimi Castle and supervised the government as the most powerful person.
After the death of Hideyoshi, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA took over Fushimi-jo Castle, and formed a government.
sen.cmt: The first translation is unnatural English. I think it is enough to say that Ieyasu "formed a government".
sen.e: After the death of Hideyoshi, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA took over Fushimi-jo Castle, and formed a government.

sen.j: やがて家康と石田三成の対立が先鋭化すると、家康は三成を挑発するために慶長5年（1600年）に伏見城の留守部隊に鳥居元忠・内藤家長・松平家忠らのわずかな部隊を残して会津征伐に赴いた。
sen.e: When Ieyasu and Mitsunari ISHIDA started to oppose radically, Ieyasu went to punitive expedition to Aizu leaving only a few units of Mototada TORII, Ienaga NAITO, and Ietada MATSUDAIRA in Fushimi Castle in 1600 to provoke Mitsunari.

When opposition from Mitsunari ISHIDA came to a head, Ieyasu made a punitive expedition to Aizu to challenge Mitsunari, leaving only a skeleton force headed by Mototada TORII, Ienaga NAITO, and Ietada MATSUDAIRA in Fushimi Castle.

When opposition from Mitsunari ISHIDA came to a head, Ieyasu made a punitive expedition to Aizu to challenge Mitsunari, leaving only a skeleton force headed by Mototada TORII, Ienaga NAITO, and Ietada MATSUDAIRA in Fushimi Castle in 1600.

sen.j: そして三成はこれが家康の挑発と知りつつも、蟄居という現状打開を謀るためにそれに乗って挙兵した。
sen.e: Mitsunari knew that Ieyasu was provoking him but raised the army to break the present condition of being confined to his house.
Although Mitsunari knew Ieyasu's intention, he raised the army to respond to Ieyasu's challenge, because he wanted anyway to break his present condition of being confined to his house.
sen.cmt: 原文があいまいです。「なぜこれが関が原の戦いにつながったのか」ということを書くとまったく別の文章を作り出すことになってしまうので、少し噛み砕いて訳しています。
sen.e: Although Mitsunari knew Ieyasu's intention, he raised the army to respond to Ieyasu's challenge, because he wanted anyway to break his present condition of being confined to his house.

sen.j: こうして、伏見城は関ヶ原の戦い前哨戦の舞台となる。
sen.e: Then, Fushimi Castle became the stage of the beginning of the Sekigahara Battle.
Fushimi-jo Castle then became the stage for the beginning of the Sekigahara Battle.
Fushimi-jo Castle then became the stage for the beginning of the Sekigahara Battle.

sen.j: 1800名程度の将兵にも関わらず籠城軍の士気は高く、西軍は4万の大軍で攻めるが豊臣秀吉の築城した名城である伏見城は堅固であった。
sen.e: Despite the officers and soldiers of approximately 1,800, the morale of besieged army was high; although the West army attacked with 40,000, Fushimi Castle, the great castle built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, was solid, and it took several days until the surrender of the castle as Mototada fought desperately, and this caused remarkable contradiction on the strategy afterward.

Despite only having a total of 1,800 officers and soldiers, the morale of besieged garrison was high, and the great Fushimi-jo Castle built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI allowed them to resist the army of the West, which numbered some 40,000 men, for some time. After some desperate fighting from Mototada, the castle eventually succumbed, but the garrison's efforts dramatically affected the strategies of the subsequent battle.
sen.cmt: Again the first translation doesn't make any sense. I have tried to guess what is meant but this needs checking!! Also, I had to split this into two sentences.
sen.e: Despite only having a total of 1,800 officers and soldiers, the morale the besieged garrison was high, and the great Fushimi-jo Castle built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI allowed them to resist the army of the West, which numbered some 40,000 men, for some time. After some desperate fighting from Mototada, the castle eventually succumbed, but the garrison's efforts dramatically affected the strategies of the subsequent battle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処定冠詞必要。 “the morale of besieged” -> ”the morale of the besieged”

sen.j: 元忠の奮戦などにより落城までの日数を要し、その後の戦略に大きな齟齬をきたした。
sen.e: After some desperate fighting from Mototada, the castle eventually succumbed, but the garrison's efforts dramatically affected the strategies of the subsequent battle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処

sen.j: 関ヶ原後、家康は豊臣氏の牽制と畿内支配の拠点という両点から、焼失した伏見城の再建に乗り出す。
sen.e: After the Sekigahara Battle, Ieyasu launched reconstruction of Fushimi Castle which was burnt down, in terms of the brake on the Toyotomi family and the base of the control of territories in the vicinity of the capital and under direct imperial rule.

After the Sekigahara Battle, Ieyasu launched a reconstruction of Fushimi-jo Castle which had been burnt to the ground, for the dual purpose of restraining Toyotomi family and providing a base to control of territories in the vicinity of the capital which were under direct imperial rule.

After the Sekigahara Battle, Ieyasu launched a reconstruction of Fushimi-jo Castle which had been burnt to the ground, for the dual purpose of restraining the Toyotomi clan and providing a base for the control of territories in the vicinity of the capital which were under direct imperial rule.
sen.cmt: 定冠詞必要。. “restraining Toyotomi ” -> ”restraining the Toyotomi ”. 意味不明瞭。 ” base to control of territories”-> “base for the control of territories”

sen.j: そして慶長8年（1603年）、家康は伏見城にて将軍宣下を受け、江戸幕府を開いた。
sen.e: Ieyasu received the imperial proclamation of shogun at Fushimi Castle in 1603 and opened the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
Ieyasu received became shogun by imperial proclamation at Fushimi Castle in 1603, and this marked the beginning of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
Ieyasu became shogun by imperial proclamation at Fushimi Castle in 1603, and this marked the beginning of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: その後、家康は慶長12年（1607年）に駿府城を正式に居城とするまで、この伏見城を拠点としている。
sen.e: Ieyasu made this Fushimi Castle his base until he officially chose Sunpu Castle as the castle of a daimyo in 1607.
Ieyasu made Fushimi-jo Castle his base, until officially selecting Sunpu Castle in 1607.
Ieyasu made Fushimi-jo Castle his base, until officially selecting Sunpu Castle in 1607.

sen.j: 家康が駿府に移った後、伏見には家康異父弟の松平定勝が遠州掛川藩より5万石で入り、ここに伏見藩が立藩した。
sen.e: After Ieyasu moved to Sunpu, Sadakatsu MATSUDAIRA, the younger brother of Ieyasu with different fathers, moved in Fushimi with 50,000 koku from the domain of Kakegawa in Enshu, and the domain of Fushimi became independent as a result.

After Ieyasu moved to Sunpu, Sadakatsu MATSUDAIRA, the younger half-brother of Ieyasu (different father), moved into Fushimi receiving the territory with a yield of 50,000 koku from the domain of Kakegawa in Enshu, and this led to the domain of Fushimi becoming independent.
sen.cmt: It is not clear what is meant by "with 50,000 koku". This required clarification.
sen.e: After Ieyasu moved to Sunpu, Sadakatsu MATSUDAIRA, the younger half-brother of Ieyasu (different father), moved into Fushimi receiving the territory with a yield of 50,000 koku from the Kakegawa Domain in Enshu, and this led to the Fushimi Domain becoming independent.

sen.j: 定勝は京都所司代の板倉勝重と共に京都守備に貢献したことから、城米2万石を下賜された。
sen.e: Sadakatsu received the jomai of 20,000 koku as the imperial grant because he contributed to the defense of Kyoto together with Katsushige ITAKURA of Kyoto shoshidai.

Sadakatsu received an imperial grant of the 20,000 koku for his contribution to the defense of Kyoto together with Katsushige ITAKURA of Kyoto shoshidai (the position which administered western Japan).
sen.cmt: Here it is not clear what "shoshidai" is. This needed clarification.
sen.e: Sadakatsu received an imperial grant of 20,000 koku for his contribution to the defense of Kyoto together with Katsushige ITAKURA of Kyoto shoshidai (the position which administered western Japan).
sen.cmt: 定冠詞不要。“of the 20,000 koku” -> “of 20,000 koku”

sen.j: また、大坂の陣においても伏見城は徳川方の重要拠点となった。
sen.e: Fushimi Castle also became the important base of the Tokugawa side at Osaka no jin Battle.
Fushimi Castle was alos an important base for the Tokugawa side in the Osaka no jin Battle.
Fushimi Castle was also an important base for the Tokugawa side in the Osaka no jin Battle.

sen.j: 豊臣氏滅亡後の元和 (日本)3年（1617年）、定勝は伊勢国桑名藩6万石へ加増移封され、代わって摂津国高槻藩4万石の内藤信正が1万石加増の上で入った。
sen.e: In 1617, after the destruction of the Toyotomi family, Sadakatsu was transferred to the domain of Kuwana in the Province of Ise with the increase to 60,000 koku, and Nobumasa NAITO of the domain of Takatsuki in the Province of Settsu with 40,000 koku entered with the increase of 10,000 koku instead.

In 1617, after the destruction of the Toyotomi family, Sadakatsu was transferred to the domain of Kuwana in the Ise Province, increasing the yield of his territory to 60,000 koku, and Nobumasa NAITO of the domain of Takatsuki in Settsu Province with 40,000 koku replaced the territory with an increase of 10,000 koku.
sen.cmt: Again it is not clear what "the increase of 60,000 koku" is. Is it some kind of payment to take control of the domain? This required explanation.
sen.e: In 1617, after the destruction of the Toyotomi clan, Sadakatsu was transferred to the Kuwana Domain in Ise Province, which had a greater yield than Fushimi of 60,000 koku; to replace Sadakatsu, Nobumasa NAITO of the Takatsuki Domain in Settsu Province was transferred to Fushimi, a territory that had a yield of 10,000 koku more than the 40,000-koku yield of Takatsuki.
sen.cmt: 定冠詞不要。 “in the Ise Province” -> “in Ise Province”“and Nobumasa NAITO of the Takatsuki Domain in Settsu Province with 40,000 koku replaced the territory with an increase of 10,000 koku.”の意味が不明なため、修正。

sen.j: しかし伏見城は豊臣氏滅亡後からは重要拠点としてみなされなくなり、信正が元和5年（1619年）7月に大坂城代として転出すると、伏見藩は廃藩となり、伏見城は伏見奉行の管轄化に置かれることとなった。
sen.e: However, Fushimi Castle was not deemed to be the important base after the destruction of the Toyotomi family and abolished after Nobumasa moved out as Osaka chamberlain in July 1619, and Fushimi Castle fell under the Fushimi magistrate.

After the demise of the Toyotomi family, however, Fushimi-jo castle was no longer deemed to be an important base, and following the transfer of the castle-keeper, Nobumasa, to Osaka-jo castle in July 1619, the domain of Fushimi was abolished, and the Castle came under the control of the shogunate administrator in Fushimi.

After the demise of the Toyotomi family, however, Fushimi-jo castle was no longer deemed to be an important base, and following the transfer of the castle-keeper, Nobumasa, to Osaka-jo castle in July 1619, the Fushimi Domain was abolished, and the Castle came under the control of the shogunate administrator in Fushimi.
sen.cmt: 注意：全体で統一されていない。これまで“family”と訳されていた「氏」が急に “clan” と訳されている。

sen.j: そして元和9年（1623年）に徳川家光が伏見城にて将軍宣下を受けた後、一国一城令に基づいて伏見城は廃城となったのである。
sen.e: When Iemitsu TOKUGAWA received the imperial proclamation of shogun at Fushimi Castle in 1623, Fushimi Castle was abolished based on the edict of one castle in one domain.

When Iemitsu TOKUGAWA became shogun by imperial proclamation at Fushimi-jo Castle in 1623, Fushimi-jo Castle was destroyed due to the edict which stated that each domain could only have a single castle.

When Iemitsu TOKUGAWA became shogun by imperial proclamation at Fushimi-jo Castle in 1623, Fushimi-jo Castle was destroyed due to the edict which stated that each domain could only have a single castle.

sen.j: その後、城跡には桃の木が植林され、伏見は桃の名所となった。
sen.e: Later, peach trees were forested at the castle ruin, and Fushimi became the sights of peach.
Later, peach trees were planted in the castle ruins, and Fushimi became famous for its peaches.
Later, peach trees were planted in the castle ruins, and Fushimi became famous for its peaches.

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉の時代が桃山時代と称されたのは、この桃の木から由来されていると言われている。
sen.e: The Momoyama Period, the name of the period of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, originates from these peach trees.
The fact that the period of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI is known as the Momoyama Period is said to derive from these peach trees.
